q:
Mark is working on Components in VueJS. He wants to create 2 basic components for his web application. Which of the following steps are correct to create his required 2 components. 
Steps

  1. Two Vue instances are created with two different div ids in .js file.
  2. Once a component is created, the name of the component becomes the custom element.
  3. Common components can be used with both view instances.
  4. Adding a template to the code will register as a global component.
Lisa is working on Components in VueJS. She has created ButtonCounter Component. Now, she wants to use this component as a custom element under which Vue instance created with new Vue?
John is working on Componets in Vuejs. He wants to build a single-file component with a .vue extension file. Then what build tools can John use?

Ben is working on Components in VueJs. He wants his component to be the starting point for rendering. Ben wants to configure his root element. Then the options need to pass to which method to configure the root component?

Lisa is working on Components in VueJS. She used createApp to configure the root component which is is used as the starting point for rendering when we mount a Vue application. He wrote the following snippet and wants to mount the root component, then what should she replace in the comment?

Code

const HackerComponent = {
  /* options */
}
const myapp = Vue.createApp(HackerComponent )
//Comment

Ben is working on Components in VueJS. He wants to register 'globals' of the application instance so that they can be used by components within that Vue app. He wrote the following snippet and wants to add a FeatureComponent, then what should he replace in the comment?

Code

const myapp = Vue.createApp({})
//Comment
myapp.directive('focus', FocusDirective)
myapp.use(LocalePlugin)

Lisa is working on components in VueJS. She has already created a few components. She wants to register a new Vue component inside another component given below. From the given options, select the option through which she can achieve the result.

Code

export default {
  el: '#oldelement'
  //Code here
}

Ben is working on Components using VueJS. He built a component, for which location in the application is not defined at build time and he wants the component to be instantiated and placed at runtime. Then which type of options Ben should go choose?

Lisa is working on Components in VueJS. She wants to develop single-page applications using various components. Then which of the following statements are true? 
Statements

  1. Components are reusable Vue instances with custom HTML elements.
  2. Components can be reused only 2 times.
  3. Components can be used in another component, making it a child component.
  4. Methods, data, computed and watch can be used in components.
  5. Vue components can be defined only globally.

What is the output of the given VueJS code snippet without any mouse interaction?

Code

<html>

<head>
    <title>VueJs Components</title>
    <script type="text/javascript" src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/vue/2.5.3/vue.min.js">
    </script>
</head>

<body>
    <div id="ct2">
        <hackercomponent></hackercomponent>
    </div>
    <div id="ct1">
        <hackercomponent></hackercomponent>
    </div>
    <script>
        Vue.component('hackercomponent', {
            template: '<div v-on:mouseover = "changename()" v-on:mouseout = "originalname();"><h1>Custom Component created by <span id = "name">{{name}}</span></h1></div>',
            data: function () {
                return {
                    name: "Mark"
                }
            },
            methods: {
                changename: function () {
                    this.name = "Ben";
                },
                originalname: function () {
                    this.name = "Mark";
                }
            }
        });
        var vm = new Vue({
            el: '#ct2'
        });
        var vm1 = new Vue({
            el: '#ct1'
        });
    </script>
</body>

</html>

Options

1.

2.

3.

4.

Consider the code snippet given alongside. The third line will throw an error because of a missing argument. In regular stateful components you access the children using this.props.children. What should be used here? What should be used here? What should be changed/added in the above code to make it work?

Code

const DispComponent= ({link}) => (
 <div>
 <a href={link}>{children}</a> 
 </div>
);

<DispComponent url="http://www.hackerearth.com">Hackerearth</PureComponent>

<a href="http://www.hackerearth.com">Hackerearth</a>

Options

1.

const DispComponent = ({link, children}) => (...) 
where "children" should be added with link in the argument section.

2.

{link}>{link} should be added in the third line.

3.

{props.children} should be added in the third line after {link}

4.

{props.link} should be added in the third line.

Consider the two code snippets given alongside. Both of them are giving errors due to one reason or the other. You have been appointed the task of finding out the kind of error in the two codes so that may be corrected afterward.

Code

I. 
render() {
 const ComponentE = enhance(MyComponent);
 return <ComponentE />;
} 

II. 
ComponentWrapped.staticMethod = function() {/*other code*/}

const ComponentE = enhance(ComponentWrapped);

typeof ComponentE.staticMethod === 'undefined'

Options

1.

I. It is not recommended to apply a HOC to a component within the render method of a component.

II. When you apply a HOC to a component the new component does not have any of the static methods of the original component.

2.

I. This is because ref is not really a prop similar to key. In this case you need to use the React.forwardRef API.

II. When you apply a HOC to a component the new component does not have any of the static methods of the original component .

3.

I. It is not recommended to apply a HOC to a component within the render method of a component. 

II. This is because ref is not really a prop similar to key. In this case you need to use the React.forwardRef API.

4.

I. This is because ref is not really a prop similar to key. In this case you need to use the React.forwardRef API. 

II. It is not recommended to apply a HOC to a component within the render method of a component.

While creating your React App, you have written exactly the same code as given alongside. But, soon you realize that it gives an error. Identify the kind of error. Select the code in the options that would debug the error.

Code

render() {
 return <button className="btn" onClick={this.handleClick()}>{'Submit Info'}</button>
}

Options

1.

render() {
 return <button className="btn" onClick={this.handleClick}>${Submit Info}</button>
}

2.

render() {
 return <button className="btn" onClick={handleClick()}>{'Submit Info'}
}

3.

render() {
 return <button className="btn" onClick={this.handleClick}>{'Submit Info'}</button>
}

4.

render() {
 return className="btn" onClick={this.handleClick}${'Submit Info'}
}

You need to add a web component to your React app. You use vaadin data picker web component. You have written the entire code. Now, you want to label it as "When did you join?". Select the appropriate code to insert in the comment.

Code

import React from 'react';
import './Style.css';
import '@vaadin/vaadin-date-picker';
class Joiner extends React.Component {
 render() {
 return (
 <div className="Disp">
 //code
 </div>
 );
 }
}
export default Joiner;

Options

1.

<vaadin label="When did you join?"></vaadin>

2.

<vaadin-date-picker label="When did you join?"></vaadin-date-picker>

3.

<vaadin-date-picker name="When did you join?"></vaadin-date-picker>

4.

<vaadin-date-picker key="When did you join?"></vaadin-date-picker>

In ReactJS, you are working on the components and props. If you have implemented the following code, then which of the following statements about this code are correct:

function Welcome(props) {
  return <h1>Hello, {props.name}</h1>;
}

const element = <Welcome name="HackerEarth" />;
ReactDOM.render(
  element,
  document.getElementById('root')
);
  1. The method ReactDOM.render() is called with the <Welcome name="HackerEarth" /> element.
  2. React calls the Welcome component with {name: 'HackerEarth'} as the stateless components.
  3. The Welcome component returns a <h1>Hello, HackerEarth</h1> element as the result.

In Azure DevOps Server, you are working on the Azure test plans. Which of the following manual tests are performed by the development teams, including developers, testers, UX teams, product owners by exploring the software systems without using test plans or test suites?
In Bootstrap 4, you are working on components. Which of the following utility classes is used to obtain alerts in the form of web links?

In Bootstrap 4, you are working on the collapse component. Which of the following statements about the collapsable attributes are correct:
    1. The data-toggle="collapse" attribute is used to control the collapsable content.
    2. The data-target="#id" attribute is used to connect the collapsable content by using the ID of the collapsable region.
    3. The data-parent and data-child attributes are used to close all the collapsable elements under a specific parent when one collapsible element is displayed.

In Bootstrap 4, which of the following statements about badges are correct:
    1. They are used to determine the type of information that is used for building any website.
    2. They are constructed by using the .badge class and the .badge-secondary contextual class.
    3. They are implemented within the elements in a Bootstrap script.
In Bootstrap 4, you are working on components. Which of the following components is used to display the hierarchy-based information for a specific website?

  2. BigQuery Command-Line tool
  3. Cloud Storage Command-Line tool

In Bootstrap 4, you are working on the spinner component. Which of the following statements about the spinner classes are correct:
    1. The spinner-border and text-warning classes are used to create an orange-colored spinner.
    2. The spinner-grow and text-info classes are used to create a light blue-colored growing spinner.
    3. The spinner-grow and spinner-grow-sm classes are used to create a smaller spinner.

In Bootstrap 4, you are working on components. Which of the following statements about the cards component are correct:
    1. The .card-content class is used to maintain content of the card component.
    2. The .card-header class is used to include the header to the content.
    3. The .list-group-flush class is used to create the list of the content.
